Award.AbstractNarration: This award is made as part of the FY 2014 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. The title of the project for this fellowship to Hiroaki Tanaka is "Lagrangian Cobordisms and Fukaya Categories, Factorization Homology and Link Invariants, Bridgeland Stability and K-Theory." The host institution for the fellowship is Harvard University, and the sponsoring scientist is Dr. Jacob Lurie.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project enhanced the understanding of several nascent topics in the fields of geometry and topology.

First, the project led to proofs of various theorems confirming that the theory of Lagrangian cobordisms has an internal algebraic structure that is compatible with the algebraic structures of the Fukaya category. (These two theories--of Lagrangian cobordisms and of Fukaya categories--are toolkits in the study of symplectic geometry, a kind of geometry inspired by classical mechanics; symplectic geometry has grown in research interest markedly over the last three decades.)

The project also led to the discovery and study of a new mathematical object, a stack classifying families of broken lines. Roughly speaking, this is a geometric object that controls the ways in which gradient trajectories (such as the descending trail of a water droplet on a surface) can acquire breaks. The phenomenon of trajectory-breaking appears in several central ideas in geometry, most notably Morse theory and Lagrangian Floer theory. This stack gives a way to translate these geometric phenomena into algebraically manipulable entities, by encoding the moduli space of breaking trajectories into a sheaf on the stack of broken lines.

Aside from these intellectual merits, support from the project allowed Tanaka to engage in several activities having a broader impact on the community. Tanaka has spoken to students at local high schools about mathematics as a career choice, led discussions with students from multiple universities about how to create an inclusive math community more conducive to research by mathematicians from all walks of life, and served as a faculty advisor for Gender Inclusivity in Mathematics, helping students organize an annual conference for women in mathematics and advocating for various policy changes within the math department.
